author: Amina Khan
text: Terrible customer service and questionable 'authenticators'. I was sold a pair of what I believe to be fake Adidas x Prada (came with no tags or box which is fine) but I took them to the Adidas store who stated it is hard to be conclusive without tags and boxes but looked at certain things like the smudged label and wonky Prade heel tab, excessive glue and uneven stitching - they are most likely fake. Their digital authenticators are clearly not good enough, and their 'customer service' assistant Emily needs to go on some training. I dropped Adidas a line to let them know that Grailed is allowing potential fakes to be sold, hopefully, that will motivate them to take it seriously. I'll be going straight to Paypal. Avoid Grailed and stick to StockX or even eBay. These are amateurs peddling questionable goods.
title: Terrible customer service and…

author: PGD
text:
So, I’m new to this platform. But, I’m a Level 4 seller on StockX, blah, blah, blah. 
My point: I’ve been around. A few sales went through great on Grailed and I received perfect feedback across the board. Then, the scams started happening. New profiles with no purchase history outright paying for the item (even if it’s above market), then being dead silent when attempting to speak with them, followed by (surprise!) an unauthorized charge claim on PayPal. Being wise to this, I put my profile on vacation mode, hoping that I could just take everything down when I had a moment. But, as soon as the clock struck midnight and my “return” day began, BOOM another sale from a silent, rando, zero transaction buyer. Immediately, I contacted Grailed and asked what I should do-that this guy fit the profile of every other fraudulent purchase I’ve received. No one bothered to reply. So, I sent the item out thinking that, after I tape recorded everything, bought insurance and signature confirmation, that I’d be good. Then along came “Gavin” from the “Grailed Team” more than 24 hours later saying to not send the item, if I did, to re-route it, and to go deal with PayPal. Yeah, too late. So, I tried rerouting it (hopefully, it’s successful) and “Gavin”/Grailed have yet again gone dead silent regarding how they can help and did not answer my questions as to, inter alia, whether this guy can still leave me negative feedback since they (Grailed) expressly told me (too late) not to do business with the buyer, etc. One could argue that I could’ve waited longer for a response. But, I pride myself on sending things out fast-StockX only gives you two business days and I’m guessing that it rests on the premise that buyers should not have to spend their hard earned money for some seller to “get around” to something they’ve paid their hard earned money for. Plus, over 24 business hours is plenty of time for Grailed to respond. Someone could also argue that I should’ve refunded the guy on the spot. But, that leaves me open to negative feedback (from what I’ve been told). With only a few sales, I can’t afford a negative review. 

TL;DR: Grailed sucks; Grailed’s mod team sucks, they offer no protection; they’re lazy; they’re rude; and scammer buyers are everywhere. I deleted every single item and they in no way, shape, or form deserve their cut of the sales. Other platforms are far from perfect. But, Grailed is a steaming pile of crap. Hopefully, StockX begins to accept used stuff or a legit middleman service that will help advocate for you (e.g. not a rando on Reddit) comes around; I’d happily pay the premium for that…
Stay safe out there, sellers! Karma is a b****, Grailed!
title: Grailed is an absolute joke

author: Julian S
text:
«Grailed Protection» doesn’t exist and is a literal scam.
Grailed proudly advertise on their website that Grailed Protection will «take over» with their Money Back guarantee if Paypal is unable to solve your refund claim or if you’re outside the 180 day period for Paypal refunds. But this is completely false. Whenever I mention Grailed Protection with customer service they stop responding to my e-mails or respond with automated mails. Horrendous costumer service and actual lies as part of their refund «policy».
title: «Grailed Protection» doesn’t exist

author: Samantha Blackburn
text:
So on June 16. I placed my order with Grails, a place you can buy matching t-shirts to go with your sneakers, two weeks I emailed customer service, they said they was having a high volume of printing and there was a delay, I gave the benefit of the doubt, then two weeks became a month they say for your waiting they will give a 15% discount which never happened.  I'm still waiting on 4 t-shirts that I find it ridiculous that a place that prints t-shirts for a business has taken going on two months to produce four.
I am now working with my bank to get back my money.
Buyer beware if you plan on ordering from them make sure you're not ordering for an occasion I still have not received my items.
title: two months and still not received my order

author: Claudia Selvatino
text: I purchased an item from a seller and after 2 weeks of attempted correspondence, it became clear the seller had no intention to send my item. Grailed was quick to refund me - I’ll absolutely give them that. But after leaving a negative review on the seller’s page about my experience, I learned that if the seller removes a listing, the review goes with it. So, if a seller gets a negative review, they can effortlessly wipe their slate clean. I can’t shop on Grailed with confidence knowing they allow their sellers to do this.
title: Easy for sellers to manipulate their rating

author: Mark
text:
Although the concept of Grailed is a good one, it has a significant number of sellers who cheat the system by being deceptive of sizing, or simply not shipping items that have been paid for.
The reliance on PayPal for refunds creates a cumbersome process and leaves buyers at risk if they do not fully understand what actions need to be done by whom and when.
I'd give it one star if it weren't for the speedy response of the Grailed Support Team and their work to resolve the multiple issues I had with purchases.
title: Nice idea for a way to buy clothes, but flawed.
